Award.AwardTitle: Search for New Phenomena at the Energy Frontier
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to search for physics that does not have an explanation in the Standard Model (SM), the theory that describes the properties of the elementary particles making up the known matter in the universe. The work will be done using the ATLAS multi-particle detector at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, the European particle physics laboratory in Switzerland. In 2012 the Higgs boson (H) was discovered at the LHC by both ATLAS and CMS, another large detector at LHC. The Higgs boson was the last particle predicted to exist by the SM. In this project the PI and his group of scientists will use the LHC running at almost twice the energy achieved in 2012, 13 teraelectron volts (TeV) as opposed to 7.5 (TeV). The group will look for events in which an H decays to a fermion anti-fermion pair. (A fermion is an elementary particle that has a half-integer value of the fundamental property of all elementary particles known as spin. An electron, for example, is a fermion.) Details of such decays, such as the frequency with which they occur, can reveal whether or not other Higgs-like particles, predicted in various extensions of the SM, exist. The increased energy will also allow the group to search for further, more massive Higgs-like states.

The award will support one PI, a postdoctoral fellow and a graduate student. The group will collect and analyze events from run II of the LHC, which begins in the summer of 2015 and continues through the end of 2017.The group will also play a role in the maintenance of the ATLAS tiled calorimeter system and the Fast TracKer trigger (FTK, part of the planned upgrade of the ATLAS detector designed to rapidly reconstruct data from the silicon-based charged particle detector system). Their analysis focus will be in the study of Higgs couplings to ff where the Fermions are from the 3rd generation (t, b, tau-nu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report summarizes the outcome of the research and education program conducted by the ATLAS (Chakraborty) group at Northern Illinois University (NIU) and funded by NSF Grant # 1506173 from August 01, 2015 to July 31, 2019. The group consisted of one faculty member (the PI), one senior research scientist, one post-doctoral research associate, four graduate and one undergraduate REU student (not all of the students were members at the same time), and a part-time electrical engineer. This grant supported approximately a third of the group's activities. About 80% of the rest came from a different NSF grant as part of a cooperative agreement. The research is directed toward searches for new phenomena using the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The group also pursued a vigorous multi-pronged public outreach program.

Members of the Chakraborty group have played, and continue to play, a number of important roles in ATLAS detector operations and physics analyses since joining the international collaboration at CERN in 2007. On behalf of NIU, the group has major institutional responsibilities in data quality monitoring (DQM) and calibration software for the Tile Hadronic Calorimeter (TileCal) detector system. It is also responsible for construction of units to supply power to the new front-end electronics system for the high-luminosity upgrade of the LHC. Among physics interests are searches for new phenomena in the Higgs sector, such as production of beyond-standard-model (BSM) Higgs bosons.

The research agenda is motivated by the urgent need for detailed investigation of the properties of the Higgs boson discovered jointly by ATLAS and CMS at the LHC in 2012. Our group is focused on measurement of the Higgs self-coupling and couplings to standard model (SM) fermions in order to determine whether this particle is the SM Higgs boson, or one of multiple scalar bosons postulated in various BSM scenarios. Many such scenarios also feature charged Higgs bosons, in which the group takes a special interest. Since Higgs-fermion couplings are proportional to the fermion mass, third generation fermions are of special interest in probing the Higgs sector. The group’s involvements in TileCal, which is crucial for making the relevant measurements, is perfectly aligned with these physics interests.

The outcomes of the project during this reporting period have met the expectations described in the proposal that led to the awarding of the grant. Although the searches did not lead to discovery of any new particle, they constrained the parameters in models aspiring to succeed the standard model of particle physics, thus informing future searches by our group and others. The services rendered to the maintenance and operations of the enormous and complex scientific apparatus (the "detector") was crucial not only for the success of the group's work, but also for that of thousands of fellow scientists from all over the world (to be fair, it must be acknowledged that the success of this group's work relied equally heavily by services rendered by those fellow scientists, as necessitated by such large-scale international collaboration). This, in turn, generated a wealth of scientific knowledge that have been published via hundreds of articles in top-tier refereed journals, and presented at international conferences. Members of this group played their fair share of role in the production of those results, writing of papers and presentation at conferences.

Outreach to K-12 students, teachers, and the general public, is an integral part of the group’s program. It features a highly active QuarkNet center at NIU that hosts annual one-day masterclasses, week-long workshops, 6-8 week summer internships, and STEMfest. Also included are visits to schools and volunteering at the monthly “Ask-a-scientist” open-house program hosted by Fermilab.

The broader impact of the group’s research and outreach programs is profound. The rigorous training in disciplined scientific research in a large collaborative environment prepares a steady stream of students and post-doctoral scientists equipped with precious skills for the next step of their careers – be it within academia or outside – to benefit not only themselves, but also the society at large. During this reporting period, one graduate student successfully defended his PhD thesis and went on to join as a post-doctoral researcher at another university, while another moved close to finishing her thesis. Both were recipients of highly competitive federally funded fellowships for graduate students (with help and support from the PI, the students wrote their own proposals to win these awards).

The research program is a part of a worldwide initiative that serves as an exemplary model of highly successful multilateral international cooperative undertaking in the public sector. The outreach program has a proven record of enhancing public awareness and interest in scientific research by educating students from K-12 through graduate school and a diverse spectrum of the wider general population. Undergraduate and graduate students participated in both research and outreach aspects of the program.
